Dr. De Luz sadly passed away last year ‚Äì leaving behind a lasting legacy as an entrepreneur, philanthropist, mentor, educator, and community leader. #HerStoryDE #WomensHistoryMonth2019
In 1985, De Luz earned her Ph.D. in Urban Affairs and Public Policy from the @UDelaware and would eventually serve on the University's Board of Trustees from 1994 -2001.

De Luz would share her entrepreneurial spirit with others by founding Management Consulting, Inc. Through this organization, she mentored aspiring business owners, helped create jobs, and continued to ensure our communities thrive.

Eventually settling in Delaware, she worked with her husband as a franchise owner of McDonald‚Äôs - becoming one of the first African American franchise owners in Wilmington, creating nearly 300 jobs in the process.

She soon entered the world of publishing, becoming the first African American female editor-in-chief for the Elementary and High School Language Arts Division at J.B. Lippincott Inc. As a publisher, she successfully argued against discriminatory language in children‚Äôs textbooks.

With an unwavering desire to educate and help others, she began her career as an educator and taught in elementary schools throughout the greater region. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WAJGfuJ5qdU&list=PLBPcxC128AjdsDW-Yrr_stz8Npor-u4QO&index=6

Dr. Lozelle De Luz was an award-winning entrepreneur, philanthropist, and educator ‚Äì focusing much of her work on improving the lives of Delawareans. #HerStoryDE #WomensHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D1Y_DToX4Acd88c.jpg
